canonical_explanation.text: Body fluids include blood and lymph. Blood consists of plasma (55%) and formed elements (45%): RBCs (erythrocytes), WBCs (leucocytes), and platelets (thrombocytes). Blood groups are classified as ABO (based on antigens A and B) and Rh (based on Rh factor). Blood coagulation involves a cascade of reactions leading to fibrin clot formation. The human heart is a four-chambered organ with two atria and two ventricles. The cardiac cycle consists of atrial systole, ventricular systole, and joint diastole. The SA node (pacemaker) initiates the heartbeat. Double circulation includes pulmonary (heart to lungs and back) and systemic (heart to body and back) circuits. The ECG records electrical activity with P, QRS, and T waves.
rules: The ABO blood group system has four groups (A, B, AB, O) based on the presence of antigens A and B on RBCs.
The cardiac cycle lasts approximately 0.8 seconds: atrial systole (0.1s), ventricular systole (0.3s), and joint diastole (0.4s).
In the ECG, the P wave represents atrial depolarisation, the QRS complex represents ventricular depolarisation, and the T wave represents ventricular repolarisation.

questions.question_text: Plasma constitutes approximately what percentage of blood?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 55%. Blood is composed of 55% plasma and 45% formed elements (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets). This means that plasma, the liquid part of blood, makes up around 55% of the total blood volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because they do not accurately represent the composition of blood. Option A) 25% is too low, as plasma makes up a larger portion of blood. Option C) 75% is too high, as the formed elements (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) account for a significant portion of blood. Option D) 45% is also incorrect, as that represents the percentage of formed elements, not the percentage of plasma.

questions.question_text: A person with blood group AB has:

options.text: Both antigens A and B on RBCs and no antibodies in plasma

questions.explanation_correct: A person with blood group AB has both antigens A and B on their red blood cells (RBCs), and no antibodies in their plasma. This combination of antigens makes them a universal recipient, as their body will not attack the A or B antigens from a blood transfusion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not accurate. Option A is incorrect because a person with blood group AB has both antigens A and B, not just antigen A. Option C is incorrect because a person with blood group AB does have antigens on their RBCs. Option D is incorrect because a person with blood group AB does not have antibodies a and b in their plasma.

questions.question_text: The universal donor blood group is:
questions.explanation_correct: The universal donor blood group is O because it does not have any A or B antigens on the red blood cells. This means that people with O blood can donate to anyone, regardless of their blood group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blood group O is the universal donor because the red blood cells do not have A or B antigens, which means they can be safely donated to people with any blood group (A, B, AB, or O). The other options (A, AB, B) are not universal donors because they have specific A or B antigens on their red blood cells, which can cause an immune reaction if transfused to someone with a different blood group.

questions.question_text: Erythroblastosis foetalis occurs when:

options.text: An Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive foetus in subsequent pregnancies, leading to antibody attack on foetal RBCs
The mother is Rh positive and father is Rh negative

questions.explanation_correct: Erythroblastosis foetalis occurs when an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive fetus in subsequent pregnancies. The mother's immune system produces antibodies that can attack the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells, leading to complications.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Erythroblastosis foetalis does not occur when both parents are Rh positive, as the fetus would also be Rh positive and the mother's immune system would not produce antibodies. Similarly, if both parents are Rh negative, the fetus would also be Rh negative, and there would be no conflict. The correct scenario is when the mother is Rh negative and the father is Rh positive, resulting in an Rh-positive fetus that triggers the mother's immune response.

questions.question_text: The coagulation of blood involves the conversion of:

options.text: Fibrinogen to fibrin by the enzyme thrombin

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B. Blood coagulation involves the conversion of the soluble protein fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin strands by the enzyme thrombin. This forms a mesh-like clot that helps stop bleeding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not accurate. Option A is incorrect because thrombin converts prothrombin into thrombin, not the other way around. Option C is incorrect because hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells, and it does not convert into fibrin. Option D is incorrect because platelets are not converted into plasma, which is the liquid part of blood.

questions.question_text: The formed elements of blood include:
questions.explanation_correct: The formed elements of blood include RBCs, WBCs, and platelets. These are the solid cellular components of blood, unlike the liquid plasma which contains water, proteins, and other dissolved substances.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because the formed elements of blood refer to the cellular components - red blood cells (RBCs), white blood cells (WBCs), and platelets. Option A is incorrect as plasma proteins are not the only formed elements. Options C and D are also incorrect as they do not include the full list of formed elements.

questions.question_text: The human heart has:

options.text: Four chambers (two atria and two ventricles)

questions.explanation_correct: The human heart has four chambers - two atria (upper chambers) and two ventricles (lower chambers). This allows for a more efficient circulation of blood throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The human heart does not have just two chambers or three chambers. It has a total of four chambers - two atria and two ventricles. This four-chambered structure is necessary for the heart to effectively pump blood to the lungs and the rest of the body through the pulmonary and systemic circuits.

questions.question_text: The SA node (sinoatrial node) is known as the pacemaker because it:

options.text: Generates electrical impulses that initiate each heartbeat

questions.explanation_correct: The SA node is called the pacemaker because it generates the electrical impulses that initiate each heartbeat, causing the heart muscles to contract and pump blood throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because the SA node is responsible for generating the electrical signals that trigger the contraction of the heart muscles, causing the heart to beat. It is not involved in directly pumping blood, receiving blood from the lungs, or producing hormones.

questions.question_text: The cardiac cycle lasts approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The cardiac cycle, which includes a complete sequence of heart contractions and relaxations, typically lasts around 0.8 seconds. This duration matches option B, making it the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cardiac cycle does not last 1.5 seconds (option A), 0.3 seconds (option C), or 2.0 seconds (option D). The correct duration of the cardiac cycle is approximately 0.8 seconds, as this is the typical time it takes for the heart to complete one full cycle of contraction (systole) and relaxation (diastole).

questions.question_text: The lub-dub sounds of the heart are produced by:

options.text: Closing of AV valves (lub) and semilunar valves (dub)

questions.explanation_correct: The 'lub-dub' sounds of the heart are produced by the closing of the atrioventricular (AV) valves (lub) and the semilunar valves (dub). This is because the closing of these valves creates vibrations that are heard as the characteristic heart sounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The 'lub-dub' sounds are not produced by the contraction of the heart muscles, the flow of blood through the arteries, or the simultaneous opening of all the valves. The closing of the AV valves and the semilunar valves creates the 'lub-dub' sounds, as the vibrations of the valve closures are what we hear as the heart sounds.

questions.question_text: The QRS complex in an ECG represents:

options.text: Ventricular depolarisation (spread of impulse through ventricles)

questions.explanation_correct: The QRS complex in an ECG represents the depolarization (spread of electrical impulse) through the ventricles of the heart. This is because the largest part of the heart's muscle mass is in the ventricles, which need to contract powerfully to pump blood out to the body and lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The QRS complex does not represent atrial depolarization or repolarization, as these events are represented by the smaller P wave and T wave in an ECG, respectively. The QRS complex is specifically associated with the larger and more powerful contraction of the ventricles, which pump blood out of the heart to the body and lungs.

questions.question_text: Cardiac output is calculated as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cardiac output is the volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute, which is calculated as the product of stroke volume (the amount of blood pumped per heartbeat) and heart rate (the number of heartbeats per minute). Therefore, the correct formula is stroke volume × heart rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options do not correctly calculate cardiac output. Blood pressure and blood volume are not factors in the calculation of cardiac output. Tidal volume and respiratory rate are measurements related to the respiratory system, not the cardiovascular system.

questions.question_text: Double circulation means blood passes through the heart:

options.text: Twice in each complete circuit (once through pulmonary and once through systemic)

questions.explanation_correct: Double circulation means the blood passes through the heart twice in each complete circuit - once through the pulmonary circulation (heart to lungs and back) and once through the systemic circulation (heart to body and back). This ensures the efficient delivery of oxygenated blood to all body parts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because in single circulation, the blood passes through the heart only once in each complete circuit. Option C is incorrect because the blood does not pass through the heart three times in each complete circuit. Option D is incorrect because the blood does pass through the heart in the circulatory system.

questions.question_text: Pulmonary circulation carries blood from the:

options.text: Right ventricle to the lungs and back to the left atrium
Left atrium to the right ventricle

questions.explanation_correct: The pulmonary circulation carries blood from the right ventricle to the lungs and back to the left atrium. This allows the blood to pick up oxygen in the lungs before it is pumped out to the body through the systemic circulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because the pulmonary circulation carries blood from the right ventricle to the lungs and back to the left atrium. The other options are incorrect - option A describes the systemic circulation, option C has the direction of flow reversed, and option D is unrelated to pulmonary circulation.

questions.question_text: Hypertension is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Hypertension is defined as persistently high blood pressure, with levels above 140/90 mmHg. This is the medical definition of hypertension, where the blood pressure remains elevated over a long period, putting strain on the heart and blood vessels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hypertension does not mean low blood pressure or irregular heartbeat. Low blood pressure is the opposite of hypertension, while irregular heartbeat is a different condition. Hypertension is specifically characterized by consistently high blood pressure, which can lead to serious health problems if left untreated.

questions.question_text: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is caused by:

options.text: Atherosclerosis â€” deposition of calcium, fat, cholesterol, and fibrous tissue in coronary arteries

questions.explanation_correct: Coronary artery disease (CAD) is caused by the buildup of plaque (made of calcium, fat, cholesterol, and fibrous tissue) in the coronary arteries that supply blood to the heart. This gradual process of atherosclerosis narrows the arteries and restricts blood flow, leading to CAD.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coronary artery disease is not caused by infections in the heart valves, overhydration, or excess hemoglobin production. CAD is specifically caused by the buildup of plaque in the coronary arteries, a process known as atherosclerosis, which restricts blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.question_text: Lymph differs from blood in that lymph:

options.text: Lacks RBCs and most plasma proteins, and is colourless

questions.explanation_correct: Lymph differs from blood in that it lacks red blood cells and most plasma proteins, making it colourless. This is the key difference between blood and lymph fluid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lymph is a clear, colourless fluid that does not contain red blood cells or most plasma proteins found in blood. It flows through a separate system of lymphatic vessels, not arteries like blood. Lymph also does not have the reddish colour of blood.

questions.question_text: The bundle of His and Purkinje fibres are part of the:

options.text: Cardiac conduction system that transmits impulses to the ventricles

questions.explanation_correct: The bundle of His and Purkinje fibres are part of the cardiac conduction system that transmits electrical impulses from the AV node to the ventricles, causing them to contract and pump blood out of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The bundle of His and Purkinje fibres are not part of the respiratory system, nervous system, or lymphatic system. They are part of the cardiac conduction system, which is responsible for coordinating the contraction of the heart's chambers to ensure efficient blood flow throughout the body.

questions.question_text: Thrombocytes (platelets) play a crucial role in:
questions.explanation_correct: Thrombocytes (platelets) play a crucial role in blood clotting (coagulation) by initiating the formation of a fibrin clot to stop bleeding. They gather at the site of injury and release clotting factors that trigger the coagulation cascade.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thrombocytes (platelets) are not involved in oxygen transport, immune response, or nutrient transport. Their primary function is to help stop bleeding by initiating the blood clotting process through the coagulation cascade.

questions.question_text: Angina pectoris is characterised by:

options.text: Acute chest pain due to insufficient oxygen supply to the heart muscle

questions.explanation_correct: Angina pectoris is characterized by acute chest pain due to insufficient oxygen supply to the heart muscle, which is the correct answer (option B). This occurs when there is a blockage or narrowing of the coronary arteries supplying blood to the heart, preventing adequate oxygen delivery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct characteristics of angina pectoris. Option A (excess fluid in the lungs) describes a condition called pulmonary edema, while option C (rupture of an artery) describes a different cardiovascular event called an aortic aneurysm. Option D (infection of the pericardium) describes a condition called pericarditis, which is different from angina pectoris.

questions.question_text: Which type of WBC is most abundant in blood?
questions.explanation_correct: Neutrophils are the most abundant type of white blood cells (WBCs) in the human body, making up about 60-70% of the total WBC count. They are the first responders to fight infections and play a crucial role in the body's immune defense system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Neutrophils. While eosinophils, basophils, and monocytes are also important types of WBCs, neutrophils are the most abundant, accounting for the majority of the total WBC count in the blood. Neutrophils are the primary immune cells that quickly respond to and fight off infections in the body.

questions.question_text: The tricuspid valve is located between the:
questions.explanation_correct: The tricuspid valve is located between the right atrium and right ventricle. This allows blood to flow from the right atrium into the right ventricle during the cardiac cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tricuspid valve is not located between the left atrium and left ventricle, the aorta and left ventricle, or the pulmonary artery and right ventricle. The tricuspid valve is specifically found between the right atrium and right ventricle, allowing blood to flow from the upper to lower right chamber of the heart.

questions.question_text: The P wave in an ECG represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The P wave in an ECG represents atrial depolarization, as the electrical impulse originates from the sinoatrial (SA) node and spreads through the atria, causing them to contract. This is the first wave observed in a normal ECG tracing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The P wave does not represent ventricular depolarization, ventricular repolarization, or Bundle of His activation. Ventricular depolarization is represented by the QRS complex, ventricular repolarization by the T wave, and the Bundle of His activation occurs between the P wave and the QRS complex.

questions.question_text: The hepatic portal vein carries blood from:
questions.explanation_correct: The hepatic portal vein carries blood from the intestine to the liver, allowing nutrients absorbed in the intestine to be processed by the liver. This is the correct answer as the liver plays a crucial role in metabolizing and distributing the nutrients from the digestive system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The hepatic portal vein does not carry blood from the liver to the heart, the heart to the liver, or the kidneys to the liver. The hepatic portal vein is responsible for transporting blood from the intestines to the liver, where the nutrients from digested food can be processed and distributed throughout the body.

questions.question_text: The Rh factor is named after the:

options.text: Rhesus monkey in which it was first discovered

questions.explanation_correct: The Rh factor is named after the Rhesus monkey, in which it was first discovered. The Rh antigen was found on the red blood cells of the Rhesus monkey, and later identified in humans as well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Rh factor is not named after a researcher, a rhinoceros, or Rh protein in bacteria. It was named after the Rhesus monkey, as this is the species in which the Rh antigen was first discovered and studied. The Rh factor is an important blood group system in humans, based on the presence or absence of the Rh antigen on red blood cells.

questions.question_text: Mature RBCs in humans lack a nucleus. This adaptation:

options.text: Provides more space for haemoglobin, increasing oxygen-carrying capacity

questions.explanation_correct: The lack of a nucleus in mature RBCs provides more space for haemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein. This increases the overall oxygen-carrying capacity of RBCs, making them more efficient at transporting oxygen throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B. Mature RBCs lack a nucleus, which does not make them less efficient or prevent them from carrying oxygen. In fact, the lack of a nucleus allows more space for haemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein, increasing the overall oxygen-carrying capacity of RBCs. The size of RBCs is not affected by the lack of a nucleus.

questions.question_text: The T wave in an ECG represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The T wave in an ECG represents ventricular repolarisation, which is the process of the ventricles returning to their resting state after contracting during ventricular systole. This is the correct answer because the T wave is the last wave in the ECG cycle, corresponding to the end of the ventricular contraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The T wave does not represent atrial depolarisation, ventricular depolarisation, or atrial repolarisation. These events are represented by other waves in the ECG: the P wave for atrial depolarisation, the QRS complex for ventricular depolarisation, and the PR interval for atrial repolarisation. The T wave specifically indicates the repolarisation (return to resting state) of the ventricles after they have contracted.

questions.question_text: Arteries carry blood:
questions.explanation_correct: Arteries carry blood away from the heart to the various tissues and organs of the body. This is because arteries are responsible for the distribution of oxygenated blood throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Arteries can carry both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood, not always oxygenated. C) Veins, not arteries, carry blood towards the heart. D) Arteries are not only found in the lungs, but throughout the body.

questions.question_text: The normal resting heart rate in an adult is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The normal resting heart rate in an adult is approximately 72 beats per minute. This heart rate is maintained by the sinoatrial (SA) node, the natural pacemaker of the heart, which generates electrical signals to regulate the heart's contractions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because 40-50 beats per minute is too low for a normal resting heart rate, 120 beats per minute is too high, and 200 beats per minute is dangerously high and would indicate a serious medical condition. The correct heart rate of 72 beats per minute is the average for most healthy adults at rest.

questions.question_text: Heart failure refers to:

options.text: The inability of the heart to pump blood effectively enough to meet the body's needs

questions.explanation_correct: Heart failure refers to the inability of the heart to pump blood effectively enough to meet the body's needs. This means the heart is not functioning properly and cannot circulate blood efficiently throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heart failure does not refer to a complete stoppage of the heart or a rupture of the heart. These are different medical conditions. A single missed heartbeat is also not considered heart failure, as it is a temporary irregularity in the heart's rhythm. Heart failure is a chronic condition where the heart is unable to pump blood effectively to meet the body's requirements.

questions.question_text: The lifespan of a mature human RBC is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The lifespan of a mature human red blood cell (RBC) is approximately 120 days. This is because RBCs are produced in the bone marrow and circulate in the bloodstream until they are broken down and removed by the spleen, liver, and bone marrow after about 120 days.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lifespan of a mature human RBC is not 7 days, 365 days, or 30 days. RBCs have a lifespan of around 120 days before they are removed from circulation. This is because RBCs are continuously produced in the bone marrow and have a finite lifetime before they are broken down and replaced by new cells.

questions.question_text: Veins have valves that:
questions.explanation_correct: Veins have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood. This ensures that blood flows in the correct direction, from the body's tissues back to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Veins do not increase blood pressure or speed up blood flow. The one-way valves in veins prevent the backflow of blood, ensuring it flows in the right direction back to the heart. Veins also do not produce hormones, which is the function of endocrine glands.

questions.question_text: The atrioventricular node (AV node) delays the cardiac impulse for about 0.1 seconds. This delay allows:

options.text: The atria to complete their contraction before ventricular contraction begins
The lungs to fill with air

questions.explanation_correct: The AV node delays the cardiac impulse for about 0.1 seconds, which allows the atria to complete their contraction before ventricular contraction begins. This ensures that blood is pumped effectively from the atria to the ventricles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The delay caused by the AV node does not allow the ventricles to relax completely, as they are still contracting. The delay also does not allow the lungs to fill with air, as that is a separate process. The delay ensures that blood flows in the correct direction, not backwards, from the atria to the ventricles.

questions.question_text: Eosinophils are WBCs that are primarily involved in:

options.text: Defence against parasitic infections and allergic reactions

questions.explanation_correct: Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell (WBC) that play a key role in defending the body against parasitic infections and allergic reactions. They are primarily involved in these processes, making option B the correct answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because eosinophils are not primarily involved in blood clotting (option A), oxygen transport (option C), or antibody production (option D). Eosinophils are a specialized type of WBC that help fight parasitic infections and allergic reactions, which is their primary function in the body.

questions.question_text: The largest artery in the human body is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The aorta is the largest artery in the human body. It carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle of the heart to the rest of the body through the systemic circulatory system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs, but it is not the largest artery. The carotid artery supplies blood to the head and neck region, and the renal artery supplies blood to the kidneys, but they are also not the largest artery in the body.

questions.question_text: Blood group O has both A and B antigens on the surface of RBCs.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is false because the blood group O does not have any A or B antigens on the surface of the red blood cells (RBCs). Instead, the RBCs of blood group O have neither A nor B antigens, making it the universal donor blood type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because blood group O does not have both A and B antigens on the surface of the RBCs. Blood group O is characterized by the absence of both A and B antigens, unlike blood groups A and B which have A or B antigens, respectively, and blood group AB which has both A and B antigens on the RBC surface.

questions.question_text: The SA node is located in the right atrium and initiates the cardiac impulse.
questions.explanation_correct: The SA (sinoatrial) node is located in the right atrium of the heart and it is the natural pacemaker that initiates the cardiac impulse, causing the heart to contract and pump blood throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect because the SA node is not located in the left atrium. The SA node is present in the right atrium and it is responsible for generating the electrical impulse that starts the heartbeat. This electrical signal then spreads through the atria, causing them to contract and pump blood into the ventricles.

questions.question_text: Pulmonary veins carry deoxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart.
questions.explanation_correct: Pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart. This is part of the pulmonary circuit, where blood flows from the heart to the lungs and back to the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood, not deoxygenated blood. Deoxygenated blood flows from the body to the heart through the vena cava, and then gets pumped to the lungs through the pulmonary arteries. After the blood gets oxygenated in the lungs, the pulmonary veins carry the oxygenated blood back to the heart.

questions.question_text: The cardiac cycle consists of one systole and one diastole, with a total duration of about 0.8 seconds.
questions.explanation_correct: The cardiac cycle consists of one atrial systole, one ventricular systole, and one joint diastole, with a total duration of about 0.8 seconds. This is because the heart's four chambers (two atria and two ventricles) contract and relax in a coordinated manner to pump blood efficiently through the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cardiac cycle does not consist of just one systole and one diastole. It actually involves three main phases: atrial systole, ventricular systole, and joint diastole. The total duration of the cardiac cycle is around 0.8 seconds, not just a single systole and diastole. Understanding the different phases of the cardiac cycle is important to comprehend how the heart pumps blood effectively.

questions.question_text: Lymph plays an important role in returning proteins and excess interstitial fluid back to the bloodstream.
questions.explanation_correct: Lymph plays an important role in returning proteins and excess interstitial fluid back to the bloodstream. Lymph vessels collect this fluid from the spaces between cells and drain it back into the bloodstream, helping to maintain the proper balance of fluids and proteins in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true because lymph is responsible for collecting excess fluid, proteins, and other substances from the spaces between cells and returning them to the bloodstream. This helps to maintain the proper fluid and protein balance in the body. If the lymphatic system did not perform this function, the excess fluid and proteins would accumulate in the tissues, leading to edema and other health problems.

questions.question_text: Blood group AB is considered the universal ___ because it has no antibodies against A or B antigens.
questions.explanation_correct: Blood group AB is considered the universal recipient because it has no antibodies against the A or B antigens. This means that a person with blood group AB can receive blood from any other blood group (A, B, AB, or O) without any immune reaction or rejection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'recipient'. Blood group AB is the universal recipient because it lacks antibodies against the A and B antigens. This means that a person with blood group AB can receive blood from any other blood group without their immune system rejecting it. The other blood groups (A, B, O) have antibodies against the antigens they lack, and so they cannot receive blood from all blood groups.

questions.question_text: The volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per beat is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The volume of blood pumped by each ventricle per beat is called the stroke volume. This is an important measure of the heart's pumping efficiency and is a key parameter in understanding the circulatory system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'stroke volume'. The stroke volume is the amount of blood pumped by each ventricle per beat, and is an essential measure of the heart's performance. It is not the same as other measures like heart rate or cardiac output.

questions.question_text: The SA node is also called the ___ of the heart because it initiates the heartbeat.
questions.explanation_correct: The SA node is called the pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical impulses that initiate the heartbeat. This specialized group of cells sets the regular rhythm and pace of the heart's contractions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pacemaker'. The SA (sinoatrial) node is the natural pacemaker of the heart because it generates the electrical signals that trigger the heart to contract and pump blood. It is not called the 'controller' or 'regulator' of the heart, but specifically the pacemaker.

questions.question_text: The cascade of reactions that leads to blood clotting and the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The cascade of reactions that leads to blood clotting and the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin is called coagulation. This process helps stop bleeding and repair damaged blood vessels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is coagulation. Coagulation is the process where a series of chemical reactions in the body lead to the formation of a fibrin clot, which helps stop bleeding. The question is asking for the name of this process, which is specifically called coagulation.

questions.question_text: The deposition of cholesterol and other substances on the inner walls of arteries is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The deposition of cholesterol and other substances on the inner walls of arteries is called atherosclerosis. This buildup of plaque can narrow and harden the arteries, leading to conditions like heart disease and stroke.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct term for the buildup of cholesterol and other substances on the inner walls of arteries is atherosclerosis. This is not the same as arteriosclerosis, which refers to the hardening and loss of elasticity of the arterial walls. Atherosclerosis is the specific condition where plaque accumulates inside the arteries, which can restrict blood flow and increase the risk of heart and cardiovascular problems.

questions.question_text: The recording of the electrical activity of the heart is called an ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The recording of the electrical activity of the heart is called an electrocardiogram (ECG). This is because the heart produces electrical impulses that can be detected and recorded using electrodes placed on the skin, and this recording is known as an ECG.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'electrocardiogram (ECG)'. This is the correct answer because the heart generates electrical impulses, and the recording of these impulses is called an electrocardiogram. It is not called a 'heartbeat' or 'cardiac activity' - those terms refer to the physical pumping of the heart, while the ECG specifically records the electrical signals that control the heart's contractions.

questions.question_text: The protein in RBCs that gives blood its red colour and carries oxygen is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The protein in red blood cells (RBCs) that gives blood its red colour and carries oxygen is haemoglobin. Haemoglobin is a iron-containing protein that binds to oxygen, allowing RBCs to transport oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'haemoglobin'. The incorrect answer could be something like 'erythrocytes' or 'plasma', which are other components of blood but not the oxygen-carrying protein. Haemoglobin is the correct answer because it is the specific protein in RBCs that gives blood its red colour and allows it to transport oxygen throughout the body.

questions.question_text: Arrange the pathway of cardiac impulse conduction in the correct order: Bundle of His, SA node, Purkinje fibres, AV node.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is SA node, AV node, Bundle of His, and Purkinje fibres. This is because the SA node acts as the natural pacemaker, triggering the electrical impulse that then passes through the AV node, Bundle of His, and finally the Purkinje fibres, which distribute the impulse to the ventricles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Bundle of His, SA node, Purkinje fibres, AV node. This is not correct because the electrical impulse originates at the SA node, then passes through the AV node before reaching the Bundle of His and Purkinje fibres. The SA node is the natural pacemaker that initiates the heartbeat, so it should be the first step in the pathway.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following blood vessels in the order of blood flow in systemic circulation: Aorta, Capillaries, Left ventricle, Veins.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of blood flow in the systemic circulation is: Left ventricle -> Aorta -> Capillaries -> Veins. This is because blood is pumped out from the left ventricle into the aorta, which then distributes it to the body's capillaries. The blood then flows back to the heart through the veins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Aorta -> Left ventricle -> Capillaries -> Veins. This is not correct because the blood flows out from the left ventricle into the aorta, not the other way around. Also, the blood flows from the aorta to the capillaries and then back to the heart through the veins, not directly from the aorta to the veins.

questions.question_text: Arrange the events of the cardiac cycle in the correct order: Joint diastole, Atrial systole, Ventricular systole.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of the cardiac cycle events is Atrial systole, Ventricular systole, and Joint diastole. This is because the atria contract first to push blood into the ventricles, followed by the ventricles contracting to pump blood out of the heart, and finally a period of joint relaxation (diastole) before the cycle repeats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Joint diastole, Atrial systole, Ventricular systole. This is wrong because the atria contract before the ventricles, not after. The ventricles contract after the atria to pump blood out of the heart, and then there is a joint relaxation period (diastole) before the cycle repeats.

questions.question_text: How do arteries differ from veins with respect to the thickness of their walls?

options.text: Arteries have thinner walls with fewer smooth muscle fibres than veins
Arteries have thicker walls with more smooth muscle and elastic tissue to withstand high blood pressure
Both arteries and veins have identical wall thickness
Veins have thicker walls because they carry deoxygenated blood

questions.explanation_correct: Arteries have thicker walls compared to veins because they contain more smooth muscle and elastic tissue in their tunica media. This structural adaptation allows arteries to withstand the high pressure generated by ventricular contraction as blood is pumped away from the heart. Veins, by contrast, operate under much lower pressure and have thinner walls with valves to prevent backflow.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because arteries have thicker, not thinner, walls than veins. Option C is wrong because arteries and veins differ markedly in wall thickness due to the different pressures they experience. Option D is incorrect because the thickness of a vessel wall is related to the pressure it withstands, not whether the blood is oxygenated or deoxygenated.

questions.question_text: How does atrial systole differ from ventricular systole in terms of duration and function?

options.text: Atrial systole lasts 0.3 s and pumps blood into the aorta; ventricular systole lasts 0.1 s and pumps blood into the atria
Atrial systole lasts about 0.1 s and pushes blood into the ventricles; ventricular systole lasts about 0.3 s and pumps blood into the pulmonary artery and aorta
Both last 0.4 s and perform identical functions
Atrial systole lasts 0.4 s and is the relaxation phase; ventricular systole lasts 0.1 s and is also a relaxation phase

questions.explanation_correct: Atrial systole lasts approximately 0.1 seconds and its function is to contract the atria, pushing blood through the AV valves into the ventricles. Ventricular systole lasts approximately 0.3 seconds and involves contraction of the ventricles, pumping blood into the pulmonary trunk (from the right ventricle) and the aorta (from the left ventricle). The longer duration of ventricular systole reflects the greater force needed to push blood into the arterial circulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the durations and functions of the two phases. Option C is incorrect because atrial and ventricular systole differ in both duration and function. Option D incorrectly labels both phases as relaxation; systole is contraction, not relaxation, and the duration values are wrong.

questions.question_text: How does pulmonary circulation differ from systemic circulation with respect to the oxygen content of the blood leaving the heart?

options.text: Pulmonary circulation carries oxygenated blood from the right ventricle; systemic carries deoxygenated blood from the left ventricle
Pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs; systemic circulation carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the body
Both circuits carry oxygenated blood away from the heart
Both circuits carry deoxygenated blood away from the heart

questions.explanation_correct: In pulmonary circulation, deoxygenated blood is pumped from the right ventricle through the pulmonary arteries to the lungs, where it gets oxygenated and returns via pulmonary veins to the left atrium. In systemic circulation, oxygenated blood is pumped from the left ventricle through the aorta to all body tissues, and deoxygenated blood returns via the venae cavae to the right atrium. The key difference is the oxygen status of the blood leaving each side of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the oxygen status of blood in each circuit. Option C is wrong because pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood. Option D is also wrong because the aorta in the systemic circuit carries oxygenated blood.

questions.question_text: How do neutrophils differ from lymphocytes in their primary immune function?

options.text: Neutrophils produce antibodies; lymphocytes perform phagocytosis
Neutrophils are primarily phagocytic and act as first responders; lymphocytes are responsible for specific immune responses including antibody production
Neutrophils are involved in allergic reactions; lymphocytes transport oxygen

questions.explanation_correct: Neutrophils are the most abundant granulocytes and function primarily as phagocytes, engulfing and destroying pathogens as the first line of cellular defence. Lymphocytes, which include B-cells and T-cells, are responsible for specific (adaptive) immune responses such as antibody production (by B-cells) and cell-mediated immunity (by T-cells). This distinction between innate phagocytic defence and adaptive specific immunity is a key concept in immunology.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the functions of the two cell types. Option C is wrong because neutrophils and lymphocytes have distinct functions. Option D is incorrect because allergic reactions primarily involve eosinophils and basophils, and lymphocytes do not transport oxygen.

questions.question_text: How does the bicuspid (mitral) valve differ from the tricuspid valve in location and structure?

options.text: The bicuspid valve has three flaps and is located on the right side; the tricuspid has two flaps on the left
The bicuspid valve has two flaps and is located between the left atrium and left ventricle; the tricuspid valve has three flaps and is located between the right atrium and right ventricle
Both valves have three flaps and are located on the same side
The bicuspid valve is a semilunar valve; the tricuspid is an atrioventricular valve

questions.explanation_correct: The bicuspid (mitral) valve has two cusps (flaps) and is located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, guarding the left AV opening. The tricuspid valve has three cusps and is located between the right atrium and the right ventricle, guarding the right AV opening. Both are atrioventricular valves, but they differ in the number of cusps and their position on opposite sides of the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the number of flaps and the locations. Option C is wrong because the two valves differ in both structure and location. Option D is incorrect because both the bicuspid and tricuspid valves are atrioventricular valves, not semilunar valves.

questions.question_text: A cell fragment that is anucleate, disc-shaped, and plays a key role in haemostasis by releasing clotting factors at the site of injury is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The described features -- anucleate cell fragment, disc-shaped, and involved in haemostasis through the release of clotting factors -- are characteristic of thrombocytes (platelets). Platelets are not true cells but cell fragments derived from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow. They aggregate at wound sites, release thromboplastin and other clotting factors, and initiate the coagulation cascade that leads to fibrin clot formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because erythrocytes are also anucleate but are biconcave discs specialised for oxygen transport, not clotting. Option B is wrong because neutrophils are nucleated phagocytic WBCs. Option D is incorrect because monocytes are the largest WBCs and differentiate into macrophages for phagocytosis, not clotting.

questions.question_text: A blood sample shows no antigens on the RBC surface but contains both anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the plasma. This blood belongs to group:
questions.explanation_correct: Blood group O is characterised by the absence of both A and B antigens on the surface of RBCs and the presence of both anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the plasma. This is why group O individuals are called universal donors -- their RBCs lack the antigens that could be agglutinated by a recipient's antibodies. However, their plasma contains antibodies against both A and B antigens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because group A has antigen A on RBCs and anti-B antibodies in plasma. Option B is wrong because group B has antigen B on RBCs and anti-A antibodies. Option C is incorrect because group AB has both A and B antigens on RBCs and no antibodies in plasma.

questions.question_text: A specialised tissue in the heart that is located at the junction of the right atrium and the superior vena cava, generates rhythmic action potentials without neural stimulation, and sets the pace for the entire heart is classified as the:
questions.explanation_correct: The features described -- located at the junction of the right atrium and superior vena cava, self-excitatory (myogenic), and sets the pace for the entire heart -- identify the sinoatrial (SA) node. The SA node is the primary pacemaker of the heart, generating action potentials at a rate of about 70-75 per minute. Its inherent rhythmicity is due to the auto-excitable nature of the nodal musculature, which does not require external nervous stimulation to initiate impulses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because the AV node is located in the lower part of the right atrium near the interatrial septum and relays impulses from the atria to the ventricles with a slight delay. Option B is incorrect because the bundle of His is located in the interventricular septum and conducts impulses from the AV node to the ventricles. Option D is wrong because Purkinje fibres are terminal conduction fibres in the ventricular walls.

questions.question_text: A blood vessel that has thin walls, a wide lumen, carries blood towards the heart, and contains semilunar valves to prevent backflow is classified as a:
questions.explanation_correct: The described features -- thin walls, wide lumen, blood flow towards the heart, and the presence of semilunar valves -- are characteristic of veins. Veins carry blood from the body's tissues back to the heart. Their thin walls and wide lumens accommodate the large volume of blood returning at low pressure. The semilunar (pocket) valves present at intervals along veins prevent the backflow of blood, especially in limbs where blood must move against gravity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because arteries have thick, muscular walls with narrow lumens and carry blood away from the heart. Option B is incorrect because capillaries are the smallest vessels with walls just one cell thick and lack valves. Option D is wrong because arterioles are small arteries that regulate blood flow into capillary beds.

questions.question_text: Riya, a medical student in a Mumbai hospital, examines a patient's ECG and observes that the interval between two consecutive QRS complexes is 1.5 seconds instead of the normal 0.8 seconds. What is the most likely interpretation?

options.text: The patient has a normal heart rate of 72 beats/min
The patient has bradycardia with a heart rate of approximately 40 beats/min
The patient has tachycardia with a heart rate of approximately 150 beats/min
The QRS complex duration has increased but the heart rate is unaffected

questions.explanation_correct: If the interval between two consecutive QRS complexes (R-R interval) is 1.5 seconds, the heart rate can be calculated as 60 / 1.5 = 40 beats per minute. This is significantly below the normal resting heart rate of about 72 beats/min and indicates bradycardia (abnormally slow heart rate). An increased R-R interval means each cardiac cycle takes longer, so fewer heartbeats occur per minute.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because a normal heart rate of 72 beats/min would produce an R-R interval of about 0.83 seconds, not 1.5 seconds. Option C is wrong because tachycardia would shorten the R-R interval, not lengthen it. Option D is incorrect because the interval between QRS complexes (R-R interval) directly determines heart rate.

questions.question_text: Amit visits a pathology clinic in Delhi for a blood test. His report shows antigen B on his RBCs and anti-A antibodies in his plasma. He is Rh-positive. Which of the following correctly describes his blood group and whom he can safely donate blood to?

options.text: Blood group A positive; can donate to A and AB
Blood group B positive; can donate to B positive and AB positive individuals
Blood group O positive; can donate to all blood groups
Blood group AB positive; can donate to AB only

questions.explanation_correct: Antigen B on RBCs and anti-A antibodies in plasma indicate blood group B. Since Amit is also Rh-positive, his complete blood group is B positive. He can safely donate blood to individuals with blood group B positive and AB positive, because their RBCs already have antigen B (and AB has both antigens), so the recipient's immune system will not attack the donated B-antigen RBCs. The Rh-positive constraint means he should donate only to Rh-positive recipients.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because group A would have antigen A on RBCs and anti-B antibodies. Option C is incorrect because group O has no antigens on RBCs. Option D is wrong because group AB has both antigens A and B on RBCs and no antibodies in plasma.

questions.question_text: Priya, a 45-year-old teacher in Bangalore, experiences chest pain during exertion that subsides with rest. Her cardiologist explains that there is partial blockage of her coronary arteries due to fatty deposits. Which condition is Priya most likely suffering from?

options.text: Angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease

questions.explanation_correct: Priya's symptoms -- chest pain during exertion that subsides with rest, along with partial blockage of coronary arteries by fatty deposits (atherosclerotic plaques) -- are characteristic of angina pectoris associated with coronary artery disease (CAD). In angina, the narrowed coronary arteries cannot supply enough oxygenated blood to the heart muscle during increased demand (exertion), causing ischaemic pain that resolves when oxygen demand decreases at rest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because heart failure refers to the heart's inability to pump blood effectively enough to meet the body's needs; it does not typically present as exertional chest pain that resolves with rest. Option C is wrong because a myocardial infarction involves complete blockage and death of heart muscle tissue, with prolonged pain that does not subside with rest. Option D is incorrect because rheumatic heart disease results from rheumatic fever damaging heart valves, not from atherosclerosis.

questions.question_text: Rohan, working in a school biology lab in Pune, observes a prepared blood smear under the microscope. He identifies a large, kidney-shaped nucleus in a cell that is the biggest among all the leucocytes. Which type of WBC has Rohan most likely identified?
questions.explanation_correct: Monocytes are the largest of all leucocytes and are characterised by a large, kidney-shaped (reniform) or horseshoe-shaped nucleus. Under a microscope, their distinctive large size and nuclear morphology set them apart from other WBCs. Monocytes circulate in the blood and migrate into tissues where they differentiate into macrophages, playing a key role in phagocytosis and antigen presentation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because neutrophils have a multilobed (typically 3-5 lobes) nucleus, not a kidney-shaped one, and are smaller than monocytes. Option B is wrong because basophils have a bilobed or S-shaped nucleus and are the rarest granulocytes. Option D is incorrect because lymphocytes are small cells with a large, round, darkly staining nucleus and very little cytoplasm.

questions.question_text: Meera, an NEET aspirant in Kochi, reads that an artificial pacemaker was implanted in a patient whose natural pacemaker had failed. Which node of the heart was dysfunctional in this patient?
questions.explanation_correct: The sinoatrial (SA) node is the natural pacemaker of the heart, located in the right atrium. It generates spontaneous electrical impulses at a rate of 70-75 per minute, setting the rhythm for the entire heart. When the SA node becomes dysfunctional (e.g., in sick sinus syndrome), the heart may beat too slowly or irregularly, and an artificial pacemaker is implanted to take over the function of generating rhythmic impulses to maintain a normal heart rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the AV node serves as a relay station that delays the impulse briefly before passing it to the ventricles; its failure would cause a heart block, not necessarily require the same type of pacemaker replacement. Option C is wrong because the bundle of His conducts impulses down the interventricular septum. Option D is incorrect because Purkinje fibres are the terminal conducting fibres in the ventricular walls.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about blood is INCORRECT?

options.text: Mature mammalian RBCs are enucleate (lack a nucleus)
Blood group O individuals have both A and B antigens on their RBCs
Platelets are involved in blood clotting
Plasma constitutes about 55% of the total blood volume

questions.explanation_correct: Option B is incorrect because blood group O individuals have neither A nor B antigens on their RBCs. This is precisely why group O is called the universal donor -- the absence of antigens means the donated RBCs will not be agglutinated by anti-A or anti-B antibodies in any recipient's plasma. A common misconception is that O stands for 'both' antigens, but it actually stands for the absence of both.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is a true statement -- mature mammalian RBCs lose their nucleus during development, which provides more space for haemoglobin. Option C is true because platelets (thrombocytes) initiate haemostasis and trigger the coagulation cascade. Option D is also true -- plasma makes up approximately 55% of blood volume, with formed elements comprising 45%.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the cardiac conduction system is INCORRECT?

options.text: The SA node has the highest rate of auto-excitation and therefore acts as the pacemaker
The AV node introduces a brief delay to allow atrial contraction to complete before ventricular contraction
The Purkinje fibres conduct impulses from the SA node directly to the ventricles, bypassing the AV node entirely
The bundle of His divides into right and left bundle branches in the interventricular septum

questions.explanation_correct: Option C is incorrect because the Purkinje fibres do not bypass the AV node. The correct pathway of impulse conduction is: SA node -> atrial musculature -> AV node -> bundle of His -> right and left bundle branches -> Purkinje fibres -> ventricular musculature. The AV node is an essential relay point in this pathway. A common student misconception is that Purkinje fibres connect directly to the SA node, but they are actually the terminal component of the conduction system, receiving impulses via the bundle branches.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct -- the SA node has the highest intrinsic rate of depolarisation (about 70-75 impulses/min) among all cardiac conduction tissues, making it the primary pacemaker. Option B is correct because the AV nodal delay (~0.1 s) ensures atrial contraction is complete before the ventricles contract. Option D is correct because the bundle of His does split into right and left branches that travel along the interventricular septum.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about blood vessels is INCORRECT?

options.text: Pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs
All arteries in the body carry oxygenated blood and all veins carry deoxygenated blood
Pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium
The aorta is the largest artery and carries oxygenated blood to systemic tissues

questions.explanation_correct: Option B is incorrect because not all arteries carry oxygenated blood and not all veins carry deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary arteries are the major exception -- they carry deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs. Similarly, the pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the left atrium. This is one of the most common misconceptions students have: arteries are defined by carrying blood away from the heart (not by oxygen content), and veins carry blood towards the heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is a true statement -- pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation. Option C is true because pulmonary veins return oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium. Option D is also true -- the aorta is the largest artery in the body and distributes oxygenated blood through the systemic circuit.

questions.question_text: Why is the wall of the left ventricle thicker than that of the right ventricle?

options.text: Because the left ventricle receives more blood from the atrium than the right ventricle
Because the left ventricle must generate higher pressure to pump blood through the entire systemic circuit, which is longer than the pulmonary circuit
Because the left ventricle produces oxygenated blood while the right ventricle produces deoxygenated blood
Because the left ventricle has more valves than the right ventricle

questions.explanation_correct: The left ventricle has a thicker myocardial wall (about three times thicker than the right ventricle) because it must generate substantially higher pressure to pump oxygenated blood through the systemic circulation, which extends to all parts of the body and offers greater vascular resistance due to its length. The right ventricle only needs to pump deoxygenated blood to the nearby lungs through the shorter, lower-resistance pulmonary circuit. This difference in workload necessitates a thicker, more muscular left ventricular wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because both ventricles receive approximately the same volume of blood per beat. Option C is wrong because the ventricles do not produce oxygenated or deoxygenated blood; they pump the blood they receive. Option D is incorrect because each ventricle has one AV valve and one semilunar valve -- the same number on both sides.

questions.question_text: Why does erythroblastosis foetalis typically not affect the first pregnancy of an Rh-negative mother carrying an Rh-positive foetus?

options.text: Because the placenta prevents any mixing of maternal and foetal blood during the first pregnancy

Because during the first pregnancy the mother is sensitised and produces anti-Rh antibodies only towards the end or during delivery, so significant antibody levels are not present to harm the first foetus
Because the first foetus is always Rh-negative regardless of the father's genotype
Because the mother's immune system is suppressed during the first pregnancy

questions.explanation_correct: During the first pregnancy, an Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh-positive foetal blood mainly during delivery (or late pregnancy), when small amounts of foetal blood may cross the placenta. This triggers the mother's immune system to begin producing anti-Rh antibodies (IgM initially, then IgG). However, the first exposure produces a relatively slow primary immune response, so significant levels of IgG anti-Rh antibodies are not built up in time to cause damage to the first foetus. In subsequent pregnancies with an Rh-positive foetus, the secondary (anamnestic) immune response is rapid and produces high levels of IgG antibodies that can cross the placenta and attack foetal RBCs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because small amounts of foetal blood can enter the maternal circulation, especially during delivery; the placenta is not a perfect barrier. Option C is wrong because the Rh status of the foetus depends on the father's genotype and can be Rh-positive in the first pregnancy. Option D is incorrect because the maternal immune system is not completely suppressed during pregnancy -- it can still mount immune responses.

questions.question_text: Why do veins have semilunar valves while arteries lack them?

options.text: Because veins carry oxygenated blood that requires directional flow control

Because blood pressure in veins is very low and blood may tend to flow backward due to gravity, so valves are needed to prevent backflow; arteries have high pressure from ventricular contraction that maintains forward flow
Because veins are closer to the heart and need more structural support
Because arteries already have valves at the point where they emerge from the heart, so internal valves are unnecessary

questions.explanation_correct: Veins carry blood back to the heart under low pressure. Especially in the limbs, venous blood must flow against gravity, making it susceptible to backflow. Semilunar (pocket) valves at intervals along veins prevent this retrograde flow, ensuring unidirectional movement of blood towards the heart. Arteries, on the other hand, receive blood directly from the powerful contractions of the ventricles, so the sustained high arterial pressure is sufficient to maintain forward flow without the need for internal valves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the presence of valves is related to blood pressure, not oxygen content -- and veins carry both oxygenated (pulmonary veins) and deoxygenated blood. Option C is wrong because veins are not necessarily closer to the heart; many veins (such as those in the legs) are far from it. Option D is partially misleading -- while semilunar valves exist at the base of the aorta and pulmonary trunk, these are at the heart-artery junction, and the reason arteries lack internal valves is the high pressure, not the presence of those junctional valves.
